search_results.full_title: Fat Funny Friend by Maddie Zahm
search_results.title: Fat Funny Friend
search_results.lyrics:
Fat Funny Friend Lyrics[Verse 1]
I break the ice, so they don't see my size
And I have to be nice, or I'll be the next punch line
I'm just the best friend in Hollywood movies
Who only exists to continue the story
The girl gets the guy, while I'm standing off-screen
So I'll wait for my cue to be comedic relief

[Chorus]
Can't be too loud, can't be too busy
If I don't answer now, are they still gonna need me?
Can't be too proud, can't think I'm pretty
Do they keep me around, so their flaws just seem silly?
[Verse 2]
I say I'm okay, 'cause they wouldn't care anyway
And I could try to explain
But my efforts in vain, they can't relate
To how I've drawn out in Sharpie where I'd take the scissors
If that's what it took for me to look in the mirror
Oh, I've done every diet to make me look thinner
So why do I still feel so goddamn inferior?

[Chorus]
Can't be too loud, can't be too busy
If I don't answer now, are they still gonna need me?
Can't be too proud, can't think I'm pretty
Do they keep me around, so their flaws just seem silly?

[Refrain]
Life of the fat, funny, friend
Life of the fat, funny, friend

[Bridge]
It's funny when I think a guy likes me
And it's funny when I'm the one who says, "Let's go to eat"
It's funny when I'm asked to go out on Halloween
Dresses, and thigh-highs, while I hide my body
Can't be too loud, and can't be too busy
If I don't answer now, are they still gonna miss me?
You might also like[Chorus]
Can't be too loud, can't be too busy
If I don't answer now, are they still gonna need me?
Can't be too proud, can't think I'm pretty
Do they keep me around, so their flaws just seem silly?

[Refrain]
Life of the fat, funny, friend
Life of the fat, funny, friend
Life of the fat, funny, friend
Life of the fat, funny, friend

[Outro]
I've drawn out in Sharpie where I'd take the scissors1Embed

description.plain: Maddie wrote this song, recounting her experience as the fat friend of a group. She has since lost the weight she had which brought her the pain she sang about, but she said the experience of growing up as the fat, funny, friend still resonates with her, and forever will.

body.plain: Maddie wrote this song, recounting her experience as the fat friend of a group. She has since lost the weight she had which brought her the pain she sang about, but she said the experience of growing up as the fat, funny, friend still resonates with her, and forever will.

annotations: I’ve drawn out in Sharpie where I’d take the scissors
When (usually) larger bodies want to be thinner they pick out every piece of them they want to get rid of and this cause them to develop self hatred for their bodies.
But my efforts in vain, they can’t relate

Fat people are often misunderstood as just being “too sensitive” or “too emotional” and their feelings are dismissed as they are considered “undesirables”. This means any attempts to comunicate their experiences often fail as the other person simply does not have what’s required to understand.

Oh, I’ve done every diet to make me look thinner
 So why do I still feel so goddamn inferior?
She feels that if she has tried to lose weight why doesn’t she feel better?
I say I’m okay, ’cause they wouldn’t care anyway

Being the fat funny friend, people don’t expect her to have problems of her own, and wouldn’t care when she does. In addition, often doctors will misdiagnose or wave off overweight patients and blame symptoms on weight
Do they keep me around, so their flaws just seem silly?
Sometimes people can feel that the only reason they are being included is so they don’t feel worse about their unimportant flaws
If I don’t answer now, are they still gonna need me?
Kate worries that if she can’t be the immediate response, they will choose someone else to fill the gap
Can’t be too loud, can’t be too busy

being fat in society means that almost everything you do is perceived negatively, so you become more mindful of everything you do.  so you try to make it up with being overcompensating, to be always available when they need you because you feel like that’s the only thing you can do to still feel like you’re wanted
Can’t be too proud, can’t think I’m pretty

Plus Size people don’t generally fit into modern beauty standers which most of the time leads to insecurity.

People tend to to think plus size people are not “pretty enough” because they don’t fit the modern beauty standards so when a plus size person is not insecure about themselves, they tend to get a lot of hate because of that.

To how I’ve drawn out in Sharpie where I’d take the scissors
 If that’s what it took for me to look in the mirror

A lot of plus-size people are insecure of how they look. Plus-sized people are generally judged since young and gain a horrible self-esteem due to the treatment from the people around them. Not just strangers online or people on the sidewalk giving looks, but often even friends, family, and partners, the people they’re closest to.

It’s common among plus-size people to wish they were smaller, skinnier and to fit the beauty standards. There are times the self-deprecation becomes so all-encompassing that they trace the parts of their body they’d cut off if they could, with sharpie.

The girl gets the guy, while I’m standing off-screen
 So I’ll wait for my cue to be comedic relief

People who don’t fit the western beauty stereotypes, such as the handicapped, disabled, or physically disproportionate to the average person in the media (too short/fat/etc) are often used in shows to bring some lightheartedness to the story, or get a laugh out of the audience because they aren’t ‘normal’ or they’re ‘undesirable’ so they just play the joker

search_results.full_title: You Might Not Like Her by Maddie Zahm
search_results.title: You Might Not Like Her
search_results.lyrics:
You Might Not Like Her Lyrics[Verse 1]
If you would've told me I'd throw away my purity ring in the middle of an airport
My younger self would laugh, would never believe that
It's against everything that we stood for
She'd hate that I've smoked weed and cuss frequently
And she'd try to convert everyone I call a "bestie"
You'll throw shots in the dark, then black out at a bar
There'll be good, then there'll be bad parts

[Chorus]
Someday, you'll kiss a girl and you'll panic
Some guy'll break your heart and you'll feel manic
Then you'll learn to let people have their opinions
And talk about your traumas
And like the body you live in
Someday, you'll learn to keep your own secrets
Say you're doing okay and really mean it
You'll lose your faith a bit and question if she's you
For a while you might not like her, but I do
[Verse 2]
Some days feel like whiplash, one-eighties
And you'll hate that you'll label yourself just to take it back
Convinced you're not bi 'cause you're way too into guys
And the first time you have sex, you'll cry
You'll sometimes skip meals and numb how you feel
And you'll miss the old you, but here's the deal
That good girl you were was really fucking bad at being real

[Chorus]
Someday, you'll kiss a girl and you'll panic
Some guy'll break your heart and you'll feel manic
Then you'll learn to let people have their opinions
And talk about your traumas
And like the body you live in
Someday, you'll learn to keep your own secrets
Say you're doing okay and really mean it
You'll lose your faith a bit and question if she's you
For a while you might not like her, but I do

[Bridge]
You might not like her, you might not like her
You might not like her, you might not like her

[Chorus]
Someday, you'll think you disappoint your parents
But they'll love you not despite, but regardless
And you'll learn to let people have shitty opinions
And talk about your traumas
And like the body you live in
Someday, you'll learn to keep your own secrets
Say you're doing okay and really mean it
You'll lose your faith a bit and question if she's you
And for a while you might not like her, but I doYou might also like1Embed

description.plain: In a Tik Tok from her account (@maddiezhams), Maddie Zham states: “Less than a year ago I wrote a song to my younger self explaining the changes (about myself) I knew she’d hate. After swearing I’d never release it, I found a team that encouraged me to. So I came out to my friends and family and signed a record deal. I promised myself if I was gonna tell the world and my old church, I was gonna do it right”. This song is a letter from Maddie now, to her younger self. She’s letting her know that it gets better. That she’s able to live as herself and that she’s proud of that.

annotatable.link_title: You Might Not Like Her by Maddie Zahm
annotatable.title: You Might Not Like Her

body.plain: In a Tik Tok from her account (@maddiezhams), Maddie Zham states: “Less than a year ago I wrote a song to my younger self explaining the changes (about myself) I knew she’d hate. After swearing I’d never release it, I found a team that encouraged me to. So I came out to my friends and family and signed a record deal. I promised myself if I was gonna tell the world and my old church, I was gonna do it right”. This song is a letter from Maddie now, to her younger self. She’s letting her know that it gets better. That she’s able to live as herself and that she’s proud of that.

annotations:
My younger self would laugh, would never believe that
 It’s against everything that we stood for

Maddie stated,

I truly believe that the 11-year-old version of me would be so disappointed in who I’ve become, but at the same time I know I’m exactly who I’m supposed to be.
If you would’ve told me I’d throw away my purity ring in the middle of an airport

Purity rings are worn to symbolize the promise not to have sex until marriage. They are typically worn on the ring finger, because they are meant to be worn until they are replaced by a wedding ring. Taking off the ring before marriage and throwing it away symbolizes the decision to no longer keep that promise.

The use of the airport as the setting of this act may symbolize that the narrator is in a transitory state of their journey between their past lifestyle and their future.
Say you’re doing okay and really mean it

In this line, Maddie is referencing her personal struggle with mental health and dealing with the stigma surrounding it that makes it difficult to talk openly about. As such, it is often times a lot easier to just say you’re fine rather than trying to explain all of the ways and reasons in which you are not, in fact, okay. In this line, she’s letting her younger self know that eventually, when she says she is fine, it will be because she actually is okay, not because she feels the need to hide the fact that she’s struggling.
Convinced you’re not bi ’cause you’re way too into guys

Sexuality is a term that covers a broad spectrum and is an incredibly personal thing. Maddie may have been in a situation where most of the people she spent time with were straight, and perhaps, by that influence and/or fear of coming out, she ignored her real feelings and convinced herself that she was straight and interested in guys, rather than people of other genders.
Some days feel like whiplash, one-eighties
Whip lash will send you in a spin, half of a circle is 180 degrees, sending you in the opposite direction
Someday, you’ll kiss a girl and you’ll panic

Growing up religiously, Maddie (assumedly) was exposed to the idea that being lgbtq+ was a sin. As such, finding joy, or comfort, or liking kissing someone of the same gender was an ‘eye-opening’ experience that she, may have, struggled to reconcile with her faith.
And like the body you live in

Maddie has been candid about her struggles with body image, especially how it affected her as she was growing up. In this line, she’s letting the young girl that she used to be, know that things get better. That loving herself, will become easier.

Someday, you’ll think you disappoint your parents
 But they’ll love you not despite, but regardless

LGBTQ+ members don’t always receive support from friends and family after “coming out”. Because of this, and so many other incomprehensible actions towards LGBTQ+ people, there is a (valid) fear of rejection or negative reaction after “coming out”. In the first line, Maddie describes how she feared that her parents would be disappointed in her for being who she is, and for living her truth. She then goes on to say that her parents rather than loving her in spite of her “shortcoming” they love her REGARDLESS. Because being an (out) member of the lgbtq+ community didn’t change the person that Maddie is/was. It only adds to the person that they love. And that feeling of acceptance and love helps.

annotations:
I break the ice, so they don’t see my size
 And I have to be nice, or I’ll be the next punch line

The artist is so consumed by societal pressures and standards that she struggles as a plus sized female. She feels obligated to overcompensate in social settings, to avoid the opportunity for a funny joke or sly comment. She feels the need to “break the ice” or create an image for herself, so their first impression is a reflection of who she is rather than noticing her size first. She emphasizes how poorly plus sized women are treated in society.

To how I’ve drawn out in Sharpie where I’d take the scissors
 If that’s what it took for me to look in the mirror
 Oh, I’ve done every diet to make me look thinner

The artist draws on a major issue within today’s society, body dysmorphia. It is not uncommon for young girls to be unsatisfied with their bodies, especially with the access to applications like FaceTune which have the ability to virtually modify one’s body to craft their “perfect” self. In the Western world, the presence of social media has caused the beauty standard to cycle through body shapes, as if women’s bodies are a trend like fashion.

In this instance, the artist feels as if she is overweight in comparison to society’s standard. It is not uncommon for females that are plus-sized to feel insecure about their bodies and receive scrutiny by not only strangers, but also loved ones. This scrutiny seems to date back to young adolescents as it is common for young girls to also be judged. Societal pressures, often leading to body dysmorphia can be so suffocating that one may go to extremes such as fad dieting or even pick out parts of their bodies with a sharpie where they wish they could remove.

And said I need to control my temper

Rather let you hurt me then love another stanger
You could burn my house down, don't know what for
And all I'd be is grateful you're back at my door
Tired of asking if you're gonna love me or not

That you had to beg me to have
Being stood up hurts double

You always say sorry then fuck up as bad
So, why am I giving you chances to mend something
We never really had?

[Chorus]
You could break my heart and I'd say "Thank you"
At least that means you think of me in some virtue
I know it sounds reckless that I put myself in danger
Rather let you hurt me then love another stanger

You could burn my house down, don't know what for

Tired of asking if you're gonna love me or not
Are you mine or a blind spot?
Are you mine or a blind spot?

It's dangerous and reckless, it's everything and manic
It's all because, it's all because it's you
It's dangerous, it's toxic, it's psycho and manic
It's everything I hate because it's you

[Chorus]
You could break my heart and I'd say "Thank you"
At least that means you think of me in some virtue
I know it sounds reckless that I put myself in danger
Rather let you hurt me then love another stanger

You could burn my house down, don't know what for
And all I'd be is grateful you're back at my door

search_results.lyrics:
Pocket Bible Lyrics[Verse]
Met some guy in my science class
Said he was gay and I didn't get that
Wish I had known it then ’cause looking back
He could have been the best friend I couldn't have

[Pre-Chorus]
Passed out advice, never passed out on drugs
Carried around judgement and labeled it love
Thought I knew how to live exactly right
The truth ain't travel sized
[Chorus]
What’s it gonna take to heal a heartbreak?
What happens when you kiss a girl for Christ's sake?
If I'm getting high, am I a mistake?
A good kid gone bad?
Why'd they start to want mе when I lost the weight?
Why do I feel bеtter when I don't pray?
I must've missed a verse that was vital
'Cause none of this was ever in my pocket bible

[Bridge]
Oh-oh, oh-oh, oh-oh, oh-oh-oh
Oh-oh, oh-oh
Oh-oh, oh-oh, oh-oh, oh-oh-oh
Oh-oh, oh-oh

[Outro]
'Cause none of this was ever in my pocket bibleYou might also likeEmbed

description.plain: Regarding Pocket Bible, Maddie Zahm stated, “When you’re raised in a church that glorifies being innocent and pure, there’s a lot of shame that comes with growing up and becoming an adult. That song is me asking all the questions that were never answered in the pocket Bibles I used to pass out at school, like ‘What happens if you kiss a girl?’ and ‘Why do I not feel better when I pray?’ I don’t think there are any answers, which is why it felt like the right introduction to a project that’s full of question marks.”

That song is me asking all the questions that were never answered in the pocket Bibles I used to pass out at school, like ‘What happens if you kiss a girl?’ and ‘Why do I not feel better when I pray?’ I don’t think there are any answers, which is why it felt like the right introduction to a project that’s full of question marks.”

annotations: Why’d they start to want me when I lost the weight?

Maddie stated

“When you lose weight, you start to see how unkind the world is to plus-sized bodies. After losing about 70 pounds I noticed that people were treating me differently, and it confirmed my fears that a lot of my social difficulties in the past had been because of my size. I was so angry.

search_results.title: Inevitable
search_results.lyrics:
Inevitable Lyrics[Verse 1]
You spent ten years with somebody
Didn't end up workin' out
And it still affects you now
I spent ten years, crippled by
Tryna be everything everybody else needs
It still affects me now

[Pre-Chorus]
And every time we end up face to face
You're overthinking from the previous day
It fades away, but you'll still find a way to
[Chorus]
Make sure we're never alone 'cause it could give me hope
If you stay too long when you're drivin' me home
So you call me a friend, again and again to try and forget
How we get too drunk and we get too close
Fallin' into each other when we already know
We could try to resist, to keep our distance
Call this what it isn't
This has more push than it ever had pull
We're inevitable

[Post-Chorus]
Oh-oh, oh-oh, oh-oh, oh
We're inevitable
Oh-oh, oh-oh, oh-oh, oh

[Verse 2]
Dinners turn into talks about our families
And understandin' each other deeply
You look out for me and it scares me
And every time I meet someone new face to face
The pieces don't fit the same
It just makes me hate the way you

[Chorus]
Make sure we're never alone 'cause it could give me hope
If you stay too long when you're drivin' me home
So you call me a friend, again and again to try and forget
How we get too drunk and we get too close
Fallin' into each other when we already know
We could try to resist, to keep our distance
Call this what it isn't
This has more push than it ever had pull
We're inevitable
You might also like[Post-Chorus]
Oh-oh, oh-oh, oh-oh, oh
We're inevitable
Oh-oh, oh-oh, oh-oh, oh

[Bridge]
We both know it's inevitable (Oh-oh, oh-oh, oh-oh, oh)
This was never in our control (Oh-oh, oh-oh, oh-oh, oh)
We both know

[Chorus]
Make sure we're never alone 'cause it could give me hope
If you stay too long when you're drivin' me home
So you call me a friend, again and again to try and forget
How we get too drunk and we get too close
Fallin' into each other when we already know
We could try to resist, to keep our distance
Call this what it isn't
This has more push than it ever had pull
Can we both admit it's out of our control?
We're inevitableEmbed

search_results.lyrics:
If It’s Not God Lyrics[Verse 1]
Be pretty and don't make it look like you're trying
Told to be Esther, when I felt like Goliath
When they were wrong, I could never keep quiet
I searched for the truth, and had faith that I'd find it

[Pre-Chorus]
Set myself on fire
Let myself be the liar

[Chorus]
All the Sundays I worried I'd disappoint my mom
'Cause I never understood some types of love being wrong
Something inside me was always steering left
What Father picks a fеw just to leave the rеst?
I heard a voice inside my head, it disagreed
So if it wasn't God, well, thank God it was me
Thank God it was me
[Verse 2]
They called me a sinner when I was a saint
Hiding in her bedroom praying depression away
Killing herself for eternal life
And losing her interest to be a good wife

[Pre-Chorus]
Set myself on fire
I let them call me the liar

[Chorus]
All the Sundays I worried I'd disappoint my mom
'Cause I never understood a type of love being wrong
Something inside me was always steering left
What Father picks a few just to leave the rest?
I heard a voice inside my head, they disagreed
So if that wasn't God, if that wasn't God, it was me
Thank God it was me

[Bridge]
Me
Thank God it was me, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah
If it was God, then I don't have to worry
He'll know why I left, why I ran in a hurry
So either way I choose, I'm not wasting my life
'Cause the voice in my head has always been right
You might also like[Outro]
All the Sundays I worried I'd disappoint my mom
'Cause I never understood a type of love being wrong
Something inside me was always steering left
No father picks a few just to leave the restEmbed

description.plain: In this song, Maddie Zahm questions her faith and wonders whether the thoughts are God’s voice or her own individual thoughts. Ultimately she is grateful that she listened to her own intuition. While promoting the song on TikTok, Maddie described it as “a letter to the church from an ex worship leader and all those reclaiming their voice”. Additionally, in an interview she said, “I came up with that song when I’d just left the church. It felt so cathartic to write, because it was the first time I’d ever acknowledged that if what I was taught by the church was God, then maybe I don’t want to believe in him”

annotatable.link_title: If It’s Not God by Maddie Zahm
annotatable.title: If It's Not God

body.plain: In this song, Maddie Zahm questions her faith and wonders whether the thoughts are God’s voice or her own individual thoughts. Ultimately she is grateful that she listened to her own intuition. While promoting the song on TikTok, Maddie described it as “a letter to the church from an ex worship leader and all those reclaiming their voice”. Additionally, in an interview she said, “I came up with that song when I’d just left the church. It felt so cathartic to write, because it was the first time I’d ever acknowledged that if what I was taught by the church was God, then maybe I don’t want to believe in him”

annotations: What Father picks a few just to leave the rest?

This is likely a reference to the New Testament of the Bible where a shepherd leaves behind ninety-nine sheep to be with one. This verse in the Bible is an allegory meant to describe the relationship that God the Father has with his children.

All the Sundays I worried I’d disappoint my mom
 ’Cause I never understood some types of love being wrong

Maddie is openly a member of the LGBTQ+ community, and used music to come out to her family. She has described finding solace in being able to “exist in full acceptance of who I am now”.

She also references types of love that break gender norms and being accepted by family in You Might Not Like Her.


Someday, you’ll kiss a girl and you’ll panic
Some guy’ll break your heart and you’ll feel manic

Someday, you’ll think you disappoint your parents
But they’ll love you not despite, but regardless
Told to be Esther, when I felt like Goliath

Esther is a character in the Torah and Old Testament of the Bible. She is willing to risk death to defend her faith, which results in her saving God’s people from genocide. As one of the few women in the Bible, she is often used as a role model for Christian girls and women.

By contrast, Goliath is the antagonist in the story of David and Goliath. He is portrayed as being a Giant, violent and in opposition to God’s people. He is ultimately killed by the physically smaller, but spiritually stronger David. His large stature is villainized.

By comparing herself to the two characters, Maddie is implying that she was told to defend her faith at all costs, but instead feels like she is warring against it.

Maddie also referenced body dysmorphia and feeling less than because of her size in Fat Funny Friend.


I break the ice, so they don’t see my size
And I have to be nice, or I’ll be the next punch line

Oh, I’ve done every diet to make me look thinner
So why do I still feel so goddamn inferior?

search_results.title: Family Reunions
search_results.lyrics:
Family Reunions Lyrics[Verse 1]
Three years imagining a life together
Loved your family more than we loved each other
I said I'd keep in touch and I did
But the more we keep in touch, the more I miss him

[Chorus]
Tell your sister if she hears from her ex
I can’t be the one that she calls
And as much as I miss talks with your dad
I need him to leave me alone
'Cause I can't find the words to express
The way that I wish I was the one
But friends don’t bring friends to family reunions
[Verse 2]
Phone calls, sweet notes, all the little things I used to love
Now they just remind me that I was never enough
We said we'd keep in touch and I tried
But the more we keep in touch, the less I move on in life

[Chorus]
Tell your sister if she hears from her ex
I can't be the one that she calls
And as much as I miss talks with your dad
I need him to leave me alone
You went and found the words to express
The way you don't think I am the one
And friends don't bring friends to family reunions
Tell your mama to stop sending me recipes she finds on the internet
And when your brother wins homecoming king
I won't be there to witness it
You went and found the words to express
The way you don't think I am the one
And friends don't bring friends to family reunions
If we’re just friends, don’t bring friends to family reunions

[Bridge]
Love them like they're my own blood
But I don’t think I'll ever move on
If you don't, if you don't
You might also like[Chorus]
Tell your sister if she hears from her ex
I can’t be the one that she calls
And as much as I miss talks with your dad
I need him to leave me alone
'Cause I can't find words to express
The way that I wish I was the one
But friends don't bring friends to family reunions
Tell your mama to stop sending me recipes she finds on the internet
And when your brother wins homecoming king
I won't be there to witness it
You went and found the words to express
The way you don't think I am the one
And friends don't bring friends to family reunions
If we're just friends don't bring friends to family reunions
If we're just friends don't bring friends to family reunionsEmbed
